headline: Kavanaugh grilled on cases during confirmation hearing
subHeadline: Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh lays out his judicial philosophy in response to questions from Senate Judiciary Committee; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: A marathon, Kavanaugh confirmation hearing is still underway. We're monitoring it. And we'll bring you the major developments as they come. Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Katie Pavlich, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." More Democratic obstruction and outbursts from left-wing protesters on Kavanaugh's first full day of questioning by the senate judiciary committee. utterances.sentences: The other thing is, is that Dem -- Republicans seem to be able to count votes a little bit better. All right. We're going to go to this hearing. Let's listen in to Brett Kavanaugh answer questions from Senator Blumenthal:

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: -- to the confidence of the American people in the judiciary and to the rule of law in the United States. But one key facet of the independence of the judiciary, as I have studied the history of nominees, is not to make commitments on particular cases.

utterances.speaker: SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL, D-CONN.
utterances.sentences: I'm not asking for a particular commitment, and I'm going to take your answer as a "no." It's really a "yes" or "no" question. You will not commit to recuse yourself. You will not commit to take yourself out of that decision, despite the unique circumstances of your nomination.

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sir, I think, to be consistent with the principle of independence of the judiciary, I should not and may not make a commitment about how I would handle a particular case. And the decision to participate in a case is itself a decision in a particular case. And therefore, following the precedent set by all the nominees before me, I need to be careful. And again, you may disagree with this, but this is part of what I see as the independence of the judiciary.

utterances.speaker: BLUMENTHAL
utterances.sentences: Well, I do disagree, and I am troubled and disturbed by your refusal to say that you will take yourself out of that kind of case. I want to move on to some examples of real-world impacts on real people. And taking that as a factor as you've articulated it in the decisions that you've made. I want to talk about Jane Doe in Garza v. Hargan. As you know, she was a 17-year-old unaccompanied minor who came across this border, having escaped serious threatening, horrific physical violence in her family, in her homelands. She braved horrific threats of rape and sexual exploitation as she crossed the border. She was eight weeks pregnant. Under Texas law, she received an order that entitled her to an abortion, and she also went through mandatory counseling, as required by Texas law. She was eligible for an abortion under that law. The Trump administration blocked her. The Office of Refugee Resettlement forced her to go to a crisis pregnancy center, where she was subjected to medically unnecessary procedures. She was punished by her continued request to terminate her pregnancy, by being isolated from the rest of the residents. She was also forced to notify her parents, which Texas law did not require. And the -- the pregnancy, which was eight weeks, was four weeks further when you participated on a panel that upheld the Trump administration in blocking her efforts to terminate her pregnancy. The decision of that panel was overruled by a full court of the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. It reversed that panel, and the decision and opinion in that case commented, quote, "The flat barrier that the government has interposed to her knowing and informed decision to end the pregnancy defies controlling Supreme Court precedent." And it said further, "The government's insistence that it must not even stand back and permit abortion to go forward for someone in some form of custody is freakishly erratic." In addition to being erratic, it also threatened her health, because she was unable to terminate her pregnancy for weeks that further increase the risk of the procedure -- one study said 38 percent every week. Her health was threatened. She was going through emotional turmoil. And yet in your dissent, you would have further blocked and delayed that termination of pregnancy. All of what I've said is correct, as to the facts here, correct?

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, Senator, I respectfully disagree in -- in various parts. My ruling, my position in the case would not have blocked --

utterances.speaker: BLUMENTHAL
utterances.sentences: It would have delayed it. And it would've set it perilously close to the 20-week limit under Texas law. Correct?

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, we were still several weeks away. I've said several things that are important, I think.

utterances.speaker: BLUMENTHAL
utterances.sentences: I want to -- I want to go on, because I can read --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. We've been watching Senator Blumenthal question Brett Kavanaugh. We've been watching this hearing all day. Guess what? Our producers are going to give all of us a treat. Don't go anywhere, because we're going to do our fun thing. "Wild Card Wednesday," it's up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. It's time for "Wild Card Wednesday." All right. I'm pulling topics that each of us has picked from inside of the hat. None of us knows which are the stories picked. Whatever, you know what I mean. OK, here's the first one. New study shows how your brain might determine if you are a procrastinator or a go-getter. Oh, well, this will be obvious. The study finds physical differences in the brain between procrastinators and go-getters. People who are prone to procrastination have a larger amygdala, which deals with emotions and have a harder time turning emotional information into action.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know what any of that means. But can't you be both? Can't you procrastinate to a certain point where you have to be a go- getter, because there's no time left.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, like you just have to rush at the end.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What do you think, Katie?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I think you can do both. Because if you're a go-getter, you have a lot on your plate. And therefore, you have to procrastinate on some things in order to get the other things done. I say I'm both.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Are you -- I don't know. You're not a procrastinator, are you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Can you come back to me on that? I don't really have -- here's the deal. There is also research that claims that procrastination is actually a - - your body's natural way of telling you you are not ready to do that job. That's why when, all of a sudden, you rush it and everything is good, but sometimes there's -- at times your body is saying, "You know what? The thought isn't there. The energy isn't there. Relax." So whenever you're procrastinating, just keep doing it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I'm going to keep justifying it with that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, sometimes if you procrastinate, Juan, it's partly because, like, you don't really want to have to deal with something.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think you're in denial. You're just putting things off.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a good thing. Maybe you should put it off.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is that why you don't prep for the show?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because -- because I know I have you here to argue with me. I can win anything. But the thing is -- the thing about this is don't you want to see a diagram of President Trump's brain?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I bet he has a huge --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's not a procrastinator.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He goes through his list of things he's accomplished.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Boom, boom, boom, boom.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: He doesn't wait on them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What does he have, a huge medulla or something?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, he doesn't have one of those. Amygdala.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: By the way, it's not the size that matters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, duly noted. All right. Companies rolling out monthly subscription service for cars. I love this idea. The auto industry --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is this your pitch?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It was my pitch. Is this good?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait, what is this again?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, so the auto industry is creating a subscription service so you can rent your next car month-to-month. So you don't have to have the same car all the time. You can, like, preplan. You know what I mean? So it's like the cost is anywhere from $380 to $1,200 a month.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- and the summer you get a convertible.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I like that idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then in the fall you can get a pick-up and haul around all your leaves.

utterances.sentences: That's what you think people do with leaves, right, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think so.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're a homeowner.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what? We're definitely moving away from owning stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Owning stuff.

utterances.sentences: Wait. Can I tell you something? I had the global entry interview. You know, where you get the thing. Do you know that they reprimanded me for not having a driver's license?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A lot of younger people don't. You could just say, you know, you're young at heart, because Kate, I know that you have a car.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But a lot of younger people don't.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I think it's cultural, too, though. Like, if you're from the West Coast, you kind of need a car to get around. Your car is your freedom. Right? Whereas in New York, you can take the subway, you can take the ferry. You can take a Zipcar, a Rent-a-Car. But out West, like, your Jeep, it's freedom.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know a guy who basically, he bought the end of the lease of a Corvette so we can have one month of his midlife crisis, Juan. In July, he wanted the Corvette.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That sounds cool to me. What's the problem with that? But the thing about this is, I like knowing that I'm getting in my car, and I've got my chewing gum here, and I've got the change here, and I've got the station set.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You have a month before that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And your liberal talking points?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: NPR, right, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. How'd you know, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I knew it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, I'm excited about this one. A tiny St. Louis apartment with kitchen-bathroom combo finds a new tenant. This is kind of unbelievable. Check out these pictures. A St. Louis apartment's unique layout, it features a kitchen and a bathroom in the same place, separated only by a toilet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I've lived in a place like this.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: That's in New York, I thought.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Two hundred square foot studio. It costs $525 a month. I mean, come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: In Idaho, 520 a month can give you a four-bedroom suite with a pool.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know who lived there? Eric Shawn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is that a short joke, because you really shouldn't talk.

utterances.sentences: I'm just only a half an inch -- I'm only that much taller than him.

utterances.sentences: Is he the only one you're taller than?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: How could this pass inspection? This cannot be hygienic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's disgusting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is that legal?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It can't be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You can even have your toothbrush close next to your toilet, because when you flush, the fecal elements fly onto your toothbrush. It's true. You don't have your toothbrush next to the toilet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Now you're cooking next to the toilet?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think that's illegal. I think you've got to have a hallway separating bathrooms and cooking.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I don't think it matters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it does.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I don't think it's illegal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's convenient. You can take a bath and cook pasta.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It might be unsanitary and not great for resale, but it's certainly not illegal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And you can sit.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what this reminds me of, because I've been in hotels in Japan that are like this. They're just tiny. I mean, there's nothing there. And now they're starting to bring these to New York but because of the high cost of hotels.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Japanese, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: One more story that we didn't get to, but it's similar. Airport security trays carry more germs than toilets, a study reveals. Is this yours?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, that was me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's a good thing to know, right? "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's true?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I love that thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Time --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- for "One More Thing" -- Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time for this!

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Dana's Corny Jokes

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: "Dana's Corny Jokes." Here we go. All right, I did a legal theme, because we're in the Supreme Court world. So I have four jokes. Are you ready? No. 1, why did the lawyer have to back up to drink? Why did the lawyer have to back up to drink?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because he just passed the bar.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Man, that's good.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's good.

utterances.sentences: It is good.

utterances.sentences: But it's a lawsuit.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The briefs is good. That's better.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We'll tell the Internet that you changed that. What do you call a short court trial? A short court trial? A brief case.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Appeal!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Those were some good ones.

utterances.sentences: That's a good one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Those were really good. All right. On to a better one. National Cheese Pizza Day is today. Now look at this piece of pizza that's enticing Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I hate cheese.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: That's a lot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- per year. Five billion pizzas are sold worldwide.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And 350 slices of pizza are eaten every second in the U.S.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You better keep up the average.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So here's to National Pizza Day.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Don't get your lawsuit dirty.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Lawsuit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan Williams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, I had pizza for lunch Saturday and crabs for dinner. And I said if I have to die, that's the perfect day to go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Everyone is going, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Anyway, talk about a thrill ride. Some tourists in Crimea were in a gold cart, going through a safari park when this happened. Yes, that sleeping lion that you see there awakens and pops into the golf cart, nuzzling the visitors.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: No way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is terrible.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's awful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Your time. Go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You go to Fox News -- is it FOXNewsPodcast.com?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Is it FOXNews.com/podcast?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know, one of those things. I have an interview, FOXNewsPodcast.com with Debra Soh. She's a sex researcher. We talk about the strangest sexual fetish known to personkind. If that's not a tease, I don't know what is. It's going to blow your mind.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Is that all?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Speaking of safer words, Merriam-Webster dictionary has added added over 840 words to their lineup, which is great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's so many.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Leading language experts say that it's important to remember that new words are added to the dictionary only when they have already been used by many people and then gradually spread to the rest of us. So some of the new entries include my favorite, one of my favorite words that I use often, is "hangry," which is irritable and angry because of hunger.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I get that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's a combination of angry and hangry -- hungry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's me all day.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Bingeable is a millennial word, because it's about watching multiple episodes or parts you can watch. So Netflix --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You know, bingeable. And zoodles, which are zucchini noodles --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I love zucchini.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Jolly Green Giant sells those now.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- that resembles a string of narrow ribbon or pasta. It's very good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
